verses.text: He who lives forever has created all things together.
verses.comment: The eternal nature of God is emphasized here as the sole Creator. The verse reflects both the timelessness and sovereignty of God, similar to the beginning of Genesis.

verses.text: The Lord alone is just, and there is no other besides Him.
verses.comment: This echoes the monotheistic confession of Israel, and affirms God’s unmatched justice. See also Isaiah’s declaration of God’s uniqueness.

verses.text: Who governs the world with the palm of his hand, and all things obey his will.
verses.comment: The hand of God is a traditional imagery for His care and authority, reminding us nothing escapes His sovereignty.

verses.text: He is king of all by his power, dividing holy things among them from profane.
verses.comment: God distinguishes and sanctifies, highlighting spiritual order—a theme fulfilled in Christ’s high priestly ministry.

verses.text: To none has he given authority to declare his works, and who can search out his marvelous deeds?
verses.comment: God’s wisdom and works are ultimately beyond full human understanding.

verses.text: Who can measure his majestic power, or who can fully recount his mercies?
verses.comment: God’s mercy and might surpass our comprehension, preparing hearts for the abundance of grace revealed in Christ.

verses.text: Man’s sum of years is as a drop of water from the sea, or as a single grain in the sand.
verses.comment: The brevity of human life is contrasted with God’s eternity, a recurring biblical theme.

verses.text: So, while God is patient with everyone, he pours his mercy over those who turn to him.
verses.comment: God’s patience and mercy towards sinners is reflected throughout Scripture, culminating in Christ’s call to repentance (Luke 15).

verses.text: He sees and knows that their end is evil; so he multiplies forgiveness.
verses.comment: God’s foreknowledge does not result in wrath, but abundant mercy, an insight fulfilled through the new covenant of grace.

verses.text: The mercy of man is toward his neighbor, but the mercy of the Lord is upon all flesh, correcting, teaching, and bringing them back as a shepherd his flock.
verses.comment: The image of the Lord as shepherd is brought to its fullness in Christ, the Good Shepherd (John 10:11).

verses.text: He has compassion on those who accept discipline, and those who eagerly seek his judgments.
verses.comment: Divine mercy is especially close to the humble and those seeking righteousness.

verses.text: My child, do not add to your sins, and do not multiply offenses.
verses.comment: An exhortation toward repentance and personal responsibility, consistent with the call of both prophets and apostles.

verses.text: Do not say, 'His compassion is great; he will forgive the multitude of my sins.' For both mercy and wrath come from him, and his fury rests upon sinners.
verses.comment: God’s mercy is not a license for sin but calls for true repentance; cf. Paul’s admonition in Romans.

verses.text: Do not delay to turn to the Lord, and do not put off day after day.
verses.comment: The present moment is the acceptable time for conversion; see Hebrews and Psalms.

verses.text: For suddenly the anger of the Lord will come, and in the time of vengeance you will perish.
verses.comment: This warns not to presume upon God's patience, but to respond swiftly to His mercy.

verses.text: Do not rely on dishonest wealth, nor say, 'I have enough.'
verses.comment: Earthly security is no substitute for dependence on God; wisdom literature consistently warns against greed.

verses.text: Nothing is more offensive than greed, and nothing more sinful than loving money.
verses.comment: A direct parallel with Paul’s teaching that the love of money is a root of all kinds of evil.

verses.text: Do not be stingy with your bread, and do not murmur when giving.
verses.comment: God loves a cheerful giver; giving generously reflects God’s own character.

verses.text: Guide your heart in all your giving, and respond with a cheerful face.
verses.comment: Sacrificial giving is a theme throughout, mirrored ultimately in Christ’s self-gift (Eph. 5:2).

verses.text: Before you speak, learn; before you fall ill, take care of your health.
verses.comment: Wisdom is in preparation and forethought in both speech and action.

verses.text: Before judgment, examine yourself; and in the day of visitation you will find mercy.
verses.comment: Self-examination is crucial before divine judgment—a practice taken seriously in worship and confession.

verses.text: Before being sick, humble yourself; when sin abounds, show repentance.
verses.comment: Humility brings healing and reconciliation—see also James 5:16 for the communal value of confession.

verses.text: Let nothing hinder you from prayer, and do not neglect to give to the poor.
verses.comment: Prayer and almsgiving are paired as means of seeking God and living in justice—see Tobit 12:8.

verses.text: Do not despise humility or insult the poor.
verses.comment: God’s heart is with the humble and poor—see also Beatitudes in Matthew 5:3.

verses.text: Do not laugh at a person in bitterness of soul, for there is One who humbles and exalts.
verses.comment: God reverses fortunes, a motif seen throughout both Old and New Testaments.

verses.text: Do not plan to harm your neighbors. Honor all living persons.
verses.comment: Echoes the second great commandment—love your neighbor as yourself.

verses.text: Do not betray a friend for worldly gain, nor let your heart stray after riches.
verses.comment: Worldly gain is fleeting compared to friendship and fidelity.

verses.text: Be steadfast in humble speech, and value discipline above gold.
verses.comment: Discipline and humility bring lasting honor, traits ultimately embodied by Christ.

verses.text: Admire not a man for his appearance, nor despise anyone for their low estate.
verses.comment: God looks at the heart, not appearances—a truth Christ repeatedly emphasized.

verses.text: For the works of the Lord are wonderful; but hidden from the children of men.
verses.comment: God’s mysterious providence urges humility; many Old Testament figures recognize God’s works are beyond searching.

verses.text: Who will announce his mighty deeds? Or who will endure them? For his mercy is distant from the sinner.
verses.comment: God’s works invite awe, but sin alienates; see the recurring call for repentance throughout Scripture.

verses.text: Now, man's life is short; therefore, abandon ill intent.
verses.comment: Human mortality is a sign for urgent moral conversion—see James.

verses.text: In every deed, remember your last end, and you will never sin.
verses.comment: Meditating on one’s mortality—known as ‘memento mori’—is a profound tradition in Christian spirituality, leading to wise and holy living. Christ urges constant readiness for his coming.
